panic disorder.description: Panic disorder is a mental health condition marked by sudden, unexpected panic attacks—intense periods of fear or discomfort—often accompanied by physical symptoms like chest pain, rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, or dizziness.
workouts: Deep breathing exercises: Calm your mind by focusing on slow, deep breaths
Yoga: Combines breathing and movement for relaxation
Mindfulness meditation: Helps reduce anxiety by staying present
Regular aerobic exercise: Boosts mood and reduces stress

vaginitis.description: Vaginitis is inflammation of the vaginal tissue, typically caused by infections (bacterial, fungal, or parasitic), hormonal imbalances, or irritants, resulting in discharge, itching, pain, or burning during urination.
workouts: Pelvic floor exercises: Strengthen pelvic muscles to reduce discomfort
Use cotton underwear: Helps keep area dry and breathable

problem during pregnancy.description: Problems during pregnancy refer to medical complications such as gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, or fetal growth restriction that can affect the health of the mother or baby during gestation.
diets: Calcium and Vitamin D (milk, cheese, fortified plant milk)
Avoid raw fish, deli meats, unpasteurized dairy
workouts: Prenatal yoga: Gentle stretches safe for pregnancy
Walking: Keeps you active and healthy

acute pancreatitis.description: Acute pancreatitis is a sudden inflammation of the pancreas that causes severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and elevated pancreatic enzymes, often due to gallstones or alcohol use.
diets: Low-fat foods (boiled vegetables, lean chicken breast)
Broths and clear liquids (chicken broth, vegetable broth)
workouts: Avoid heavy lifting: Prevent strain on pancreas
Breathing exercises: Reduce stress and pain

asthma.description: Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing recurrent wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing, often triggered by allergens, exercise, or cold air.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (egg yolks, fortified milk)
workouts: Swimming: Low-impact cardio good for lungs
Avoid strenuous workouts during flare-ups: Prevent attacks

infectious gastroenteritis.description: Infectious gastroenteritis is an intestinal infection caused by viruses, bacteria, or parasites, leading to symptoms like diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and fever.
workouts: Rest: Allow the body to recover
Gentle walking: Only after symptoms improve
Hydration focus: Replenish fluids before any activity
Avoid strenuous exercise: Prevent worsening dehydration

acute sinusitis.description: Acute sinusitis is a temporary inflammation or infection of the sinuses, usually following a cold, causing nasal congestion, facial pain, pressure, and headache.
workouts: Nasal breathing exercises: Help open airways
Avoid cold-weather workouts: Prevent sinus aggravation

cornea infection.description: Cornea infection (keratitis) is an infection of the transparent front part of the eye, usually caused by bacteria, fungi, or viruses, leading to eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and light sensitivity.
diets: Vitamin A-rich foods (carrots, sweet potatoes, spinach)
workouts: Rest the eyes: Avoid screen-heavy workouts

marijuana abuse.description: Marijuana abuse refers to the excessive or harmful use of cannabis, which can lead to cognitive impairment, altered judgment, addiction, and long-term mental health issues.
diets: Foods rich in B vitamins (eggs, poultry, leafy greens)
workouts: Cardio workouts: Boost dopamine and mood
Yoga: Improve focus and reduce cravings
Group activities: Enhance social motivation and discipline

bursitis.description: Bursitis is inflammation of the bursae—small fluid-filled sacs that cushion bones and joints—causing joint pain, swelling, and limited movement, often from repetitive motion or pressure.
workouts: Gentle range-of-motion exercises: Prevent joint stiffness
Low-impact cardio: Like swimming or cycling
Avoid pressure on joints: Use proper form and padding

actinic keratosis.description: Actinic keratosis is a rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by prolonged sun exposure, and is considered a precancerous condition that can develop into squamous cell carcinoma.
workouts: Walking in shaded areas: If outdoor movement needed

chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (c.description: COPD is a group of progressive lung diseases, including emphysema and chronic bronchitis, characterized by airflow limitation, coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.
workouts: Stationary biking: Low strain on lungs

spondylosis.description: Spondylosis is a degenerative condition affecting the spine due to aging, resulting in stiffness, pain, and reduced mobility due to wear and tear on spinal discs and joints.
diets: Calcium-rich foods (milk, cheese, fortified plant milk)
Vitamin D-rich foods (egg yolk, fortified cereals)
workouts: Neck and back stretches: Improve mobility
Tai chi or yoga: Low-impact balance and movement
Avoid high-impact sports: Prevent joint stress

injury to the arm.description: Injury to the arm refers to damage to muscles, bones, ligaments, or skin in the arm area from trauma, leading to pain, swelling, bruising, or limited movement.
workouts: Isometric strengthening: Build muscles without movement
Avoid overuse: Prioritize rest and pacing

complex regional pain syndrome.description: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a chronic pain condition usually affecting a limb after injury, with symptoms including burning pain, swelling, and sensitivity to touch.
precautions: Avoid injury to the affected limb
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (fortified milk, egg yolks)

injury to the trunk.description: Injury to the trunk includes trauma to the chest, abdomen, or back areas, possibly involving internal organs, muscles, or bones, and can range from minor bruises to serious internal damage.
workouts: Breathing exercises: Ease pain and tension
Avoid twisting movements: Reduce risk of re-injury

vulvodynia.description: Vulvodynia is chronic pain or discomfort around the opening of the vagina (vulva) with no identifiable cause, often described as burning, stinging, or irritation.
workouts: Breathing techniques: Help with stress-linked flares
Avoid bike riding: Prevent pressure on sensitive area

concussion.description: A concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury caused by a blow to the head or body, resulting in temporary loss of brain function, such as confusion, memory loss, or dizziness.
workouts: Walking: Light activity to reintroduce movement
Avoid screens and bright lights: Limit visual strain

hypoglycemia.description: Hypoglycemia is a condition characterized by abnormally low blood sugar levels, often causing shakiness, sweating, confusion, irritability, or fainting, common in diabetics on insulin.
workouts: Strength training: Builds muscle mass to support glucose use
Avoid fasted workouts: Always eat before
Frequent breaks: Monitor sugar levels during activity

hiatal hernia.description: A hiatal hernia occurs when the upper part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity, often causing symptoms like heartburn, reflux, and chest pain.
workouts: Gentle walking or cycling: Support digestion
Upright posture: During and after exercise

allergy.description: An allergy is an overreaction of the immune system to substances like pollen, food, or medications, causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, rash, or anaphylaxis.
workouts: Indoor workouts: Avoid pollen and triggers
Yoga: Calms body and immune system
Swimming in clean pools: Clears airways
Avoid exercising in high pollution: Protect respiratory health

acute bronchospasm.description: Acute bronchospasm is a sudden constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, often triggered by asthma or allergens, causing wheezing and difficulty breathing.
diets: Omega-3 fatty acids (wild salmon, chia seeds)
workouts: Rest until stable: Avoid exertion during flare-ups

degenerative disc disease.description: Degenerative disc disease is a condition where spinal discs break down over time, leading to back pain, reduced flexibility, and sometimes nerve compression.
medications: Surgery (e.g., spinal fusion in advanced cases)
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (fatty fish, egg yolk)
workouts: Avoid heavy lifting: Prevent worsening symptoms

pain after an operation.description: Pain after an operation (postoperative pain) is discomfort or soreness at the surgical site, which may be due to tissue injury, inflammation, or healing processes.
workouts: Deep breathing: Prevent lung complications post-surgery
Avoid high-intensity activity: Allow full healing

injury to the leg.description: Injury to the leg includes trauma to any part of the leg such as the thigh, knee, shin, or ankle, potentially involving muscles, bones, or ligaments.
workouts: Non-weight-bearing exercises: Like swimming or seated stretches
Balance exercises: Reduce fall risk later

gout.description: Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by buildup of uric acid crystals in joints, leading to sudden, severe pain, redness, and swelling, often in the big toe.
workouts: Low-impact exercises: Like cycling or swimming
Joint mobility drills: Keep joints flexible
Stretching: Reduce stiffness in affected areas

otitis media.description: Otitis media is a middle ear infection that commonly affects children, causing ear pain, fever, irritability, and sometimes fluid discharge from the ear.
diets: Avoid dairy if it increases mucus
workouts: Avoid swimming: Prevent water exposure to ears
Neck stretches: Relieve ear canal pressure

acute kidney injury.description: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a sudden loss of kidney function due to illness, injury, or toxins, leading to buildup of waste products in the blood.
diets: Potassium regulation (bananas, potatoes – based on medical advice)
workouts: Gentle activity: Like walking during recovery
Avoid dehydration: Prioritize fluids with workouts
Strength training: Only when kidney function stabilizes
Workouts under supervision: Monitor vital signs

threatened pregnancy.description: A threatened pregnancy refers to early pregnancy complications, such as vaginal bleeding or cramping, that may suggest a risk of miscarriage but with a still viable fetus.
precautions: Avoid stress and lifting heavy items
diets: Avoid alcohol, caffeine, and high-mercury fish
workouts: Modified bed rest: Based on doctor's advice
Pelvic floor (Kegel) exercises: Safe for pelvic support

gum disease.description: Gum disease (periodontal disease) is an infection and inflammation of the gums and surrounding tissues, often caused by poor oral hygiene, leading to bleeding, receding gums, and tooth loss.
workouts: Oral hygiene focus: Brush and floss regularly
Avoid sugary sports drinks: Prevent bacterial growth
No specific physical activity restriction: Follow general wellness plan

gastrointestinal hemorrhage.description: Gastrointestinal hemorrhage is bleeding that occurs anywhere along the digestive tract, often presenting as vomiting blood or black, tarry stools, and can be caused by ulcers, varices, or cancer.
workouts: Rest: Avoid strenuous activity during active bleeding
Breathing exercises: Manage stress on the digestive system

anxiety.description: Anxiety is a mental health condition characterized by excessive worry, nervousness, or fear that interferes with daily activities, often accompanied by physical symptoms like restlessness, sweating, or rapid heartbeat.
workouts: Walking in nature: Calms the mind
Tai chi: Improve mental and emotional balance

conjunctivitis due to allergy.description: Allergic conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva (eye lining) caused by allergens like pollen or dust, leading to red, itchy, watery eyes without infectious discharge.
workouts: Indoor exercises: Avoid allergens like pollen

drug reaction.description: A drug reaction is an adverse response to a medication, ranging from mild rashes or stomach upset to severe allergic responses like Stevens-Johnson syndrome or anaphylaxis.
diets: Balanced diet with antioxidants (berries, leafy greens)
Vitamin C and E-rich foods (nuts, seeds, citrus)
workouts: Rest: While recovering from adverse reactions
Avoid sun exposure: If on photosensitive medications

macular degeneration.description: Macular degeneration is an eye disorder that damages the macula, the part of the retina responsible for central vision, leading to blurred or loss of central vision, typically in older adults.
workouts: Balance training: Prevent falls due to vision changes
Walking: Improves circulation and eye health
Indoor cycling: Safe with limited vision

pneumonia.description: Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi, resulting in cough, fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing due to inflammation and fluid in the lungs.
workouts: Gradual reintroduction to physical activity: To build endurance

vaginal cyst.description: A vaginal cyst is a fluid-filled sac that forms along the vaginal wall, often benign and asymptomatic, but can sometimes cause discomfort or pain if enlarged or infected.
workouts: Pelvic floor exercises: Support area and reduce discomfort

carpal tunnel syndrome.description: Carpal tunnel syndrome is a condition caused by compression of the median nerve in the wrist, leading to numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand and fingers.
workouts: Hand-strengthening exercises: Use putty or bands
Yoga: Helps with posture and nerve health

nose disorder.description: Nose disorders include structural or inflammatory issues such as deviated septum, nasal polyps, or rhinitis, causing congestion, breathing difficulty, or nosebleeds.
diets: Warm fluids and anti-inflammatory foods (ginger, honey)
workouts: Indoor cycling: Low impact on facial pressure
Avoid inversion poses: Prevent sinus pressure
Gentle cardio: Avoid dry, dusty air

dental caries.description: Dental caries (tooth decay) is the destruction of tooth enamel due to acids produced by bacteria feeding on sugars, leading to cavities, tooth pain, and infection if untreated.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (fatty fish, fortified cereals)
workouts: Hydration focus: Water during exercise to reduce acid
Regular workouts: Support overall oral health
No intense jaw activities: Prevent further damage

hypertensive heart disease.description: Hypertensive heart disease includes conditions caused by chronic high blood pressure, such as heart failure, thickened heart muscle, or coronary artery disease.
workouts: Avoid heavy lifting: Prevent blood pressure surges

seasonal allergies (hay fever).description: Seasonal allergies, or hay fever, are allergic reactions to airborne allergens like pollen, causing sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy eyes, and throat irritation, often during specific seasons.
precautions: Keep windows closed during high pollen
workouts: Yoga: Manage immune and stress response
Wear a mask outdoors: If walking outside

fungal infection of the hair.description: Fungal infection of the hair, or tinea capitis, is a scalp infection caused by dermatophyte fungi, resulting in scaly patches, hair loss, and sometimes black dots or swelling.
workouts: Avoid shared gym equipment: Prevent spread
Dry scalp after workouts: Prevent fungus growth

rectal disorder.description: Rectal disorders include conditions affecting the rectum such as hemorrhoids, fissures, or prolapse, often causing pain, bleeding, or difficulty during bowel movements.
workouts: Pelvic floor exercises: Strengthen rectal support
Gentle yoga: Focus on posture and breathing

stye.description: A stye is a red, painful lump near the edge of the eyelid caused by a bacterial infection of an oil gland, often resolving on its own or with warm compresses.
workouts: Low-intensity workouts: No eye rubbing or strain
Avoid hot yoga: May worsen swelling

heart attack.description: A heart attack (myocardial infarction) occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked, leading to chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and potentially life-threatening damage to heart muscle.
diets: Limit saturated and trans fats (processed foods, fried foods)
workouts: Avoid high-intensity training: Until medically cleared

obstructive sleep apnea (osa).description: OSA is a sleep disorder where the throat muscles intermittently relax and block the airway, causing repeated pauses in breathing during sleep and leading to poor rest and fatigue.
workouts: Yoga: Improve breathing and sleep quality
Avoid late-night workouts: Prevent sleep disruption

psoriasis.description: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition causing rapid skin cell growth that results in thick, scaly, red patches, often on the elbows, knees, or scalp.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (egg yolk, fortified cereals)
workouts: Swimming in saltwater: May soothe skin
Moderate aerobic activity: Supports immune system
Stretching and yoga: Gentle on skin

arthritis of the hip.description: Arthritis of the hip involves inflammation and degeneration of the hip joint cartilage, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility, commonly due to osteoarthritis.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (fortified milk, egg yolk)
workouts: Walking with support: Use cane if needed
Strength training: Build support muscles around joint

sickle cell crisis.description: Sickle cell crisis is a painful episode in people with sickle cell disease, where misshapen red blood cells block blood flow, causing severe pain, fatigue, and potential organ damage.
workouts: Rest: Avoid physical stress during crisis
Hydration focus: Essential during and after workouts
Avoid high altitudes: Prevent oxygen drop

otitis externa (swimmer's ear).description: Otitis externa is an infection of the outer ear canal, often due to trapped water and bacteria, leading to ear pain, itching, swelling, and discharge.
medications: Topical antibiotic ear drops (e.g., Ciprofloxacin + Hydrocortisone)
diets: Vitamin C-rich foods (citrus fruits, bell peppers)
workouts: Protect ears: Use dry earplugs during workouts

acute bronchiolitis.description: Acute bronchiolitis is a common lower respiratory tract infection in infants, usually caused by RSV, leading to wheezing, coughing, and difficulty breathing.
workouts: Rest during illness: Avoid all exertion
Light walking: Only after full recovery
Avoid dusty or polluted areas: Protect airways

pyogenic skin infection.description: A pyogenic skin infection is a bacterial infection of the skin that produces pus, such as abscesses, boils, or cellulitis, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
workouts: Avoid shared gym equipment: Prevent spread
Stretching at home: Avoid sweating on infected skin
Use clean towels: Hygiene is key

noninfectious gastroenteritis.description: Noninfectious gastroenteritis refers to inflammation of the stomach and intestines not caused by infection, but by irritants like medications, alcohol, or food intolerances.
diets: Avoid spicy, fatty, and dairy foods

benign prostatic hyperplasia (bph).description: BPH is a non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland in older men, causing difficulty urinating, weak stream, or frequent urination, especially at night.
workouts: Pelvic floor exercises: Improve urinary control

spinal stenosis.description: Spinal stenosis is the narrowing of the spinal canal, often due to arthritis or disc problems, leading to back pain, numbness, and weakness in the legs.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (egg yolk, fortified cereals)
workouts: Avoid arching or extension exercises: Prevent nerve irritation

acute bronchitis.description: Acute bronchitis is inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, typically caused by a viral infection, resulting in cough, mucus production, chest discomfort, and low-grade fever.
diets: Vitamin C-rich foods (citrus fruits, bell peppers)
workouts: Avoid cold-air workouts: Prevent airway constriction

croup.description: Croup is a viral infection that causes swelling of the airway in young children, leading to a barking cough, hoarseness, and difficulty breathing, often worse at night.
precautions: Seek medical help for breathing difficulty
diets: Soft, easy to swallow foods (soups, smoothies)
workouts: Gentle play: Indoors and calm once recovering

idiopathic excessive menstruation.description: Idiopathic excessive menstruation refers to abnormally heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding without an identifiable underlying medical cause.
workouts: Pelvic floor workouts: Support reproductive organs
Avoid intense cardio: Prevent symptom worsening

ear drum damage.description: Ear drum damage (tympanic membrane perforation) is a tear or hole in the eardrum due to infection, injury, or loud noise, which may cause pain, hearing loss, or drainage.
workouts: Protect ears from loud music/explosive sports

temporary or benign blood in urine.description: Temporary or benign hematuria is the presence of blood in the urine without a serious underlying cause, sometimes triggered by exercise, medications, or mild infections.
diets: Balanced diet with fruits and vegetables
workouts: Hydration before and after: Support urinary health
Avoid heavy lifting: Prevent internal pressure

common cold.description: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, typically causing sneezing, sore throat, nasal congestion, cough, and mild fever.

depression.description: Depression is a mental health disorder characterized by persistent sadness, loss of interest or pleasure, fatigue, and changes in sleep or appetite, significantly impacting daily life.
diets: Vitamin D-rich foods (egg yolk, fortified cereals)
workouts: Aerobic exercise: Boosts mood via endorphins
Walking in nature: Proven to reduce symptoms

idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle.description: Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle refers to inconsistent or unpredictable menstrual periods without a clear medical cause, often linked to hormonal imbalance.
diets: Avoid caffeine and high sugar foods
workouts: Avoid excessive exercise: Can disrupt cycles

schizophrenia.description: Schizophrenia is a severe psychiatric disorder involving distortions in thinking, perception, emotions, language, and behavior, often with hallucinations or delusions.
workouts: Structured group workouts: Promote social interaction
Walking or jogging: Boosts brain chemicals
Tai chi: Improves focus and calm
Avoid sensory overload: Choose quiet environments

sepsis.description: Sepsis is a life-threatening response to infection where the body’s immune system causes widespread inflammation, leading to tissue damage, organ failure, and possibly death.
diets: Vitamin C and zinc-rich foods (citrus fruits, pumpkin seeds)
Consult doctor for specific nutritional support
workouts: Rest and rehabilitation: After acute phase
Avoid overexertion: Recovery can be long-term

cholecystitis.description: Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, often due to gallstones, causing severe upper abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and tenderness.
workouts: Avoid core strain: Prevent gallbladder pressure

cystitis.description: Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder, usually from a bacterial infection, leading to frequent, painful urination and lower abdominal discomfort.

hemorrhoids.description: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anus or rectum that cause pain, itching, bleeding, or discomfort during bowel movements.
workouts: Walking: Reduces pressure on rectal veins

contact dermatitis.description: Contact dermatitis is a skin inflammation caused by exposure to an irritant or allergen, resulting in redness, itching, blisters, or dryness.
workouts: Avoid sweating heavily: Can irritate skin
Clean skin after exercise: Prevent flare-ups

sinus bradycardia.description: Sinus bradycardia is a slower than normal heart rate originating from the sinus node, which may be normal in athletes or caused by medications or medical conditions.
diets: Balanced diet with adequate electrolytes (potassium from bananas, magnesium from nuts)
workouts: Light aerobic activity: Walking or slow cycling
Warm-up and cool-down: Essential to prevent dizziness

pelvic inflammatory disease.description: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an infection of the female reproductive organs, often caused by sexually transmitted bacteria, leading to abdominal pain, fever, and abnormal discharge.

liver disease.description: Liver disease refers to a range of disorders affecting the liver, such as hepatitis, fatty liver, or cirrhosis, potentially causing jaundice, fatigue, and liver dysfunction.
workouts: Avoid strenuous workouts: Can worsen fatigue
Avoid alcohol-based environments (gyms with bars etc.): Stay safe

chronic constipation.description: Chronic constipation is a long-term condition characterized by infrequent or difficult bowel movements, often accompanied by abdominal discomfort or bloating.
workouts: Hydration pre- and post-workout: Key support

skin polyp.description: A skin polyp (skin tag) is a small, benign growth of skin that typically appears in areas where skin rubs together, like the neck, armpits, or groin.
precautions: Avoid irritation or injury to area
diets: Balanced diet with antioxidants (berries, leafy greens)
workouts: Monitor any changes during workout routines

brachial neuritis.description: Brachial neuritis is inflammation of the brachial plexus nerves, causing sudden shoulder and arm pain followed by weakness or numbness.

esophagitis.description: Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, commonly due to acid reflux, infections, or medications, causing pain when swallowing and chest discomfort.
diets: Avoid spicy, acidic, and fatty foods

diverticulitis.description: Diverticulitis is inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon wall, leading to abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits.
diets: Low-fiber diet during flare-up (white bread, white rice)
Gradual increase to high-fiber diet (fruits, vegetables, whole grains)
Avoid nuts and seeds during flare-ups
workouts: Walking: Light and easy on digestion
Avoid heavy weights: Prevent abdominal strain
Hydration support during and after workouts

sprain or strain.description: A sprain is a stretched or torn ligament, while a strain is a stretched or torn muscle or tendon; both cause pain, swelling, and limited movement.
workouts: Gentle range-of-motion exercises: After pain subsides
Avoid re-injury: Use supports if needed

idiopathic painful menstruation.description: Idiopathic painful menstruation (primary dysmenorrhea) is severe menstrual cramping without an identifiable medical condition, often starting in adolescence.
workouts: Yoga: Especially child’s pose and reclined twist
Avoid high-intensity workouts during pain spikes

eustachian tube dysfunction (ear disorde.description: Eustachian tube dysfunction occurs when the tube connecting the middle ear to the throat becomes blocked or fails to open, causing pressure, pain, or hearing issues.
medications: Surgical placement of ear tubes (in severe cases)
workouts: Avoid pressure changes: No underwater or flying sports
Breathing and jaw exercises: Promote drainage

appendicitis.description: Appendicitis is inflammation of the appendix, usually requiring surgery, and causes sudden lower right abdominal pain, nausea, and fever.
precautions: Don’t eat or drink before surgery

hyperemesis gravidarum.description: Hyperemesis gravidarum is a severe form of morning sickness in pregnancy, leading to persistent nausea, vomiting, dehydration, and weight loss.
workouts: Avoid fast movements: Prevent triggering symptoms

urinary tract infection.description: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of the urinary system, commonly the bladder, causing pain during urination, urgency, and cloudy or strong-smelling urine.
diets: Avoid caffeine, alcohol, and spicy foods
workouts: Walking: Gentle activity safe during mild infections
Avoid workouts that apply pressure to bladder
Pelvic floor exercises: Strengthen urinary control

peripheral nerve disorder.description: Peripheral nerve disorders affect the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord, leading to numbness, weakness, pain, or coordination problems.
diets: Vitamin B-rich foods (whole grains, eggs, leafy greens)

sebaceous cyst.description: A sebaceous cyst is a noncancerous bump beneath the skin, filled with oily material, often caused by blocked sebaceous glands.
precautions: Get it drained by a doctor if needed
workouts: Avoid pressure or friction on cyst
Walking or yoga: With non-abrasive clothing
Avoid helmets/hats if cyst is on scalp

spontaneous abortion.description: Spontaneous abortion (miscarriage) is the loss of a pregnancy before 20 weeks, often due to genetic issues or unknown causes, and may involve bleeding and cramping.
workouts: Gentle stretching: Emotional and physical recovery
Walking: When emotionally and physically ready
Avoid strenuous exercise: Until cleared by doctor

gallstone.description: Gallstones are hardened deposits of digestive fluid in the gallbladder that can block bile flow, causing abdominal pain, nausea, and sometimes infection.
precautions: Follow up for surgical evaluation if needed
diets: Avoid fried foods and refined carbs
workouts: Breathing exercises: Reduce stress and spasm

multiple sclerosis.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the protective sheath of nerves, leading to weakness, vision problems, and coordination issues.
workouts: Seated resistance training: Build strength safely

angina.description: Angina is chest pain or discomfort due to reduced blood flow to the heart muscle, often triggered by exertion or stress, and relieved by rest or medication.
diets: Avoid trans fats and red meat
workouts: Walking on flat ground: Safe cardiovascular option
No heavy lifting: Can trigger symptoms

skin pigmentation disorder.description: Skin pigmentation disorders involve changes in skin color due to excess or lack of melanin, such as vitiligo, melasma, or hyperpigmentation.
workouts: Avoid sun exposure: Exercise indoors or with protection
Low-sweat activities: Prevent friction and inflammation

personality disorder.description: Personality disorders are mental health conditions involving rigid and unhealthy patterns of thinking, functioning, and behaving that impair social or occupational life.
workouts: Walking or running: Structured routine helps mood
Yoga or tai chi: Promote mindfulness
Supervised fitness coaching: Builds discipline and trust

strep throat.description: Strep throat is a bacterial throat infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, leading to sore throat, fever, swollen glands, and red tonsils with white patches.
workouts: Avoid cardio: While febrile or sore throat
Hydration and vocal rest after workouts

developmental disability.description: Developmental disabilities are chronic conditions that begin in childhood and affect physical, learning, language, or behavioral areas, such as autism or intellectual disability.
medications: Medications (e.g., Risperidone for irritability in autism)
workouts: Balance and core work: Tailored to individual ability

chronic back pain.description: Chronic back pain is persistent or recurring pain in the back lasting more than three months, often due to structural issues, nerve damage, or degenerative conditions.
diets: Calcium and Vitamin D (milk, cheese, eggs)

heart failure.description: Heart failure is a condition where the heart can't pump blood effectively, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, fluid retention, and reduced exercise capacity.
diets: Avoid red meat and saturated fats

conjunctivitis.description: Conjunctivitis (pink eye) is inflammation of the conjunctiva of the eye due to infection or allergy, resulting in redness, discharge, and eye irritation.
workouts: Avoid water sports: Prevent further irritation
Gentle indoor walking: Prevent eye strain

herniated disk.description: A herniated disk occurs when the inner gel-like core of a spinal disc bulges out through a tear, pressing on nearby nerves and causing back pain, numbness, or weakness.
diets: Vitamin D and calcium (fortified foods, milk)

diaper rash.description: Diaper rash is skin irritation in the diaper area of infants or adults using diapers, often caused by moisture, friction, or infection.
diets: For older babies: Avoid acidic foods (tomatoes, citrus)
workouts: Gentle motion in open diapers (for infants)

eczema.description: Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic skin condition that causes itchy, inflamed, red, and dry skin, often triggered by allergens, stress, or irritants.
